title: China Eximbank provides $168.3 million preferential buyer's credit for Phase 1 of National Broadband Network Project (Linked to Project ID#58397)
description: On July 19, 2012, China Eximbank and Cameroon's Ministry of Economy, Planning, and Regional Development (MINEPAT) signed a preferential buyer credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 33 TOTAL NO.(221)] worth $168,300,000 (CFA 99 billion) for the National Broadband Network Project (Projet National Broadband Network).  The terms of the loan were as follows: a 20 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 0.30% commitment fee, and a 0.30% management fee. The proceeds of the loan were on-lent to Cameroon Telecommunications Co. (CAMTEL) to finance its $198,000,000 commercial contract with Huawei Technologies, which was signed on December 31, 2010.   As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 78.5 billion. Its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 105 billion as of December 31, 2016, CFA 92 billion as of December 31, 2017, CFA 90 billion as of December 31, 2018, and CFA 88 billion as of December 31, 2019.   This project had fiber-to-the-home, submarine cable, 4th generation mobile broadband (LTE), security surveillance network, and digital TV installation components.   Huawei Technologies was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The implementation of the project commenced on January 1, 2012 and reached completion on February 18, 2016.  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for Phase 1 of National Broadband Network Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese name of this project is 喀麦隆国家宽带网建设项目. The French project title is Projet de Réseau National à Haut débit. 2. The loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via SourceID#68635 or https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20485652-cmr_2012_178. 3. The project ID number for this transaction in Cameroon's Development Assistance Database (DAD) is CAM/000816. 4. Phase 2 of this project is captured in linked Project ID#58397. 5. The loan identification number in the Government of Cameroon's Commonwealth Secretariat Debt Recording and Management System (CS-DRMS) is 2012105.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides $168.3 million preferential buyer's credit for Phase 1 of National Broadband Network Project (Linked to Project ID#58397)

# Description
On July 19, 2012, China Eximbank and Cameroon's Ministry of Economy, Planning, and Regional Development (MINEPAT) signed a preferential buyer credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 33 TOTAL NO.(221)] worth $168,300,000 (CFA 99 billion) for the National Broadband Network Project (Projet National Broadband Network).  The terms of the loan were as follows: a 20 year maturity, a 5 year grace period, a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 0.30% commitment fee, and a 0.30% management fee. The proceeds of the loan were on-lent to Cameroon Telecommunications Co. (CAMTEL) to finance its $198,000,000 commercial contract with Huawei Technologies, which was signed on December 31, 2010.   As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 78.5 billion. Its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 105 billion as of December 31, 2016, CFA 92 billion as of December 31, 2017, CFA 90 billion as of December 31, 2018, and CFA 88 billion as of December 31, 2019.   This project had fiber-to-the-home, submarine cable, 4th generation mobile broadband (LTE), security surveillance network, and digital TV installation components.   Huawei Technologies was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The implementation of the project commenced on January 1, 2012 and reached completion on February 18, 2016.  There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for Phase 1 of National Broadband Network Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In January 2019, Cameroon unilaterally withheld debt service payments to China Eximbank. The lender responded by withholding new loan disbursements. Then, in July 2019, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed a debt rescheduling agreement (as captured via Project ID#88213). Under the terms of the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to reschedule 18 loans previously contracted by the Government of Cameroon — with scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 — by allowing the borrower to defer scheduled principal repayments between July 2019 and March 2022 to later dates but without any maturity extensions. The total amount of restructured debt was equivalent CFA 148 billion ($253 million) — or 70% of the loan principal that was scheduled for repayment between July 2019 and March 2022. Under the terms of the agreement, the Government of Cameroon agreed to repay 30% of the loan principal according to the original July 2019-March 2022 schedule (i.e. without any payment deferrals). The lender and the borrower also agreed to cancel the committed but undisbursed loan balances worth approximately CFA 10 billion (for certain loans with disbursement deadlines that had already passed). Then, in January 2020, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) classified the Government Cameroon as facing a high risk of debt distress. Eighteen months later, during an address before Cameroon’s National Assembly on June 28, 2021, the Minister of Water and Energy (MINEE) Gaston Eloundou Esommba provided an update on the ICBC-financed Bini à Warak Hydroelectric Power Plant Project. He noted that the project had been 'on hold' since November 2019 because ICBC suspended the loan agreement, even though the Government of Cameroon had already mobilized XAF 22 billion of counterpart funding. He also explained that 'the reason for this suspension is that Cameroon did not settle some of its debts towards China on time, so, it is in a cross-default situation.’
justification: Project focuses on communications infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: National Broadband Network Project with fiber-to-the-home, submarine cable, LTE, security surveillance, and digital TV components

title: Chinese Team Provides a 6.9 million RMB grant and Technical Assistance to Yaounde's Multipurpose Stadium Staff (linked to #31867, #31869)
description: In 2009, China began a program to follow up on their construction of the multipurpose stadium built by Shanxi Construction in Yaounde from 2006-2008 (see ProjectID#31867) through technical training for managing the facilities. According to Cameroon's Aid Management System, the China Development Bank committed to a grant of 6,900,000 RMB to Cameroon's Ministry of Sports and Physical Education for this technical cooperation agreement.   This consisted of two phases, each lasting two years. January 1st, 2012 marked the start date of the project.  The first phase was from 2009-2011, which concluded with a donation of maintenance tools to the stadium (see linked ProjectID#31869), and on September 25, 2012, China and Cameroon signed an agreement to provide the second phase of technical training for operating the multipurpose stadium. This training by Chinese engineers aimed at providing skills for good management of the facilities, specifically how to use central air conditioning systems, electrical lighting systems, sound reinforcement systems, large-screen systems, drainage systems, including equipment maintenance, and other general maintenance and operations techniques. Cameroonian recipients expressed appreciation to Shanxi Corporation for this technical training. Cameroon's Aid Management System reported that the training was "ongoing" in July 2014. Further construction on the Yaounde's Multipurpose Stadium occurred on 1/2016.
staff_comments: An unknown sector of the Chinese Government is the funder but the grant proceeds were disbursed through a CDB account that was established with a host country bank.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Team Provides a 6.9 million RMB grant and Technical Assistance to Yaounde's Multipurpose Stadium Staff (linked to #31867, #31869)

# Description
In 2009, China began a program to follow up on their construction of the multipurpose stadium built by Shanxi Construction in Yaounde from 2006-2008 (see ProjectID#31867) through technical training for managing the facilities. According to Cameroon's Aid Management System, the China Development Bank committed to a grant of 6,900,000 RMB to Cameroon's Ministry of Sports and Physical Education for this technical cooperation agreement.   This consisted of two phases, each lasting two years. January 1st, 2012 marked the start date of the project.  The first phase was from 2009-2011, which concluded with a donation of maintenance tools to the stadium (see linked ProjectID#31869), and on September 25, 2012, China and Cameroon signed an agreement to provide the second phase of technical training for operating the multipurpose stadium. This training by Chinese engineers aimed at providing skills for good management of the facilities, specifically how to use central air conditioning systems, electrical lighting systems, sound reinforcement systems, large-screen systems, drainage systems, including equipment maintenance, and other general maintenance and operations techniques. Cameroonian recipients expressed appreciation to Shanxi Corporation for this technical training. Cameroon's Aid Management System reported that the training was "ongoing" in July 2014. Further construction on the Yaounde's Multipurpose Stadium occurred on 1/2016.
justification: Project focuses on technical training and capacity building for stadium management, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Technical training for stadium management, focus on facility operations and maintenance skills

title: 16th Chinese medical team
description: On August 28, 2012, the 16th medical team of 45 members arrived in Cameroon. 12 of the 45 members are also members of the previous medical team (15th medical team). The team worked at Yaounde Gynaeco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital, Mbalmayo District Hospital, and Guider District Hospital for two years. China has been sending medical teams to Cameroon every two years since 1975. Shanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
16th Chinese medical team

# Description
On August 28, 2012, the 16th medical team of 45 members arrived in Cameroon. 12 of the 45 members are also members of the previous medical team (15th medical team). The team worked at Yaounde Gynaeco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital, Mbalmayo District Hospital, and Guider District Hospital for two years. China has been sending medical teams to Cameroon every two years since 1975. Shanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare provision with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services at multiple hospitals

title: MOFCOM provides Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health with CNY 4 million worth of Anti-Malarial Drugs via 2012 ETCA (Projet de fourniture des médicaments antipaludiques)
description: On September 25, 2012, China's Ministry of Commerce signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) with Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health to provide 4 million CNY worth of anti-malarial drugs manufactured in China (Projet de fourniture des médicaments antipaludiques).  The anti-malarial drugs were delivered on September 25, 2013.  Since 2010, China has put effort into treating malaria in Cameroon as well as other African countries.
staff_comments: MOFCOM is the funder but the grant proceed for the drugs were disbursed through a CDB account that was established with a host country bank.
combined_text:

The anti-malarial drugs were delivered on September 25, 2013.  Since 2010, China has put effort into treating malaria in Cameroon as well as other African countries.

evidence: Anti-malarial drugs provision, healthcare sector focus

title: China Eximbank provides $31.832 million loan to CAMTEL for unspecified purpose in 2012 (Linked to Project ID#31230)
description: On April 21, 2012, China Eximbank and and CAMTEL — a state-owned telecommunications and Internet service provider in Cameroon — signed a $31,832,494 loan agreement for an unspecified purpose. The loan carries the following borrowing terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 13.2 billion. According to the Government of Cameroon’s Caisse Autonome d'Amortissements, the loan is not backed by a repayment guarantee from the Government of Cameroon.
staff_comments: 1. China Eximbank issued a separate $31.832 million buyer’s credit (with different borrowing terms) to CAMTEL for Additional 350,0000 Lines CDMA Project in 2010 for the Additional 350,0000 Lines CDMA Project (captured via Project ID#31230). According to the Government of Cameroon’s Caisse Autonome d'Amortissements, the $31,832,494 buyer’s credit that China Eximbank issued in 2010 is backed by a repayment guarantee from the Government of Cameroon, but the $31,832,494 loan that China Eximbank issued in 2012 is not. 2. The proceeds of the loan were likely used to enable CAMTEL’s acquisition of wireless (CDMA) phone technology and facilitate the installation of CDMA lines. However, this issue requires further investigation. 3. The $31,832,494 loan that China Eximbank issued to CAMTEL in 2012 is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020. Nor is it included it in the China’s Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University's Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides $31.832 million loan to CAMTEL for unspecified purpose in 2012 (Linked to Project ID#31230)

# Description
On April 21, 2012, China Eximbank and and CAMTEL — a state-owned telecommunications and Internet service provider in Cameroon — signed a $31,832,494 loan agreement for an unspecified purpose. The loan carries the following borrowing terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate and its outstanding amount was equivalent to CFA 13.2 billion. According to the Government of Cameroon’s Caisse Autonome d'Amortissements, the loan is not backed by a repayment guarantee from the Government of Cameroon.
justification: Project involves telecommunications infrastructure with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan to telecommunications and Internet service provider, unspecified purpose, no environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center Construction Project
description: On February 16, 2012, Chinese ambassador Sun Haichao and Central African Republic (CAR) Minister of International Cooperation Doroday Amy Marazapa signed a cooperation agreement to build a Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center in the prefecture of Ombella-M'Poko. The agreement stipulated that the Chinese Government would build the demonstration center free of charge. Shanxi International Economic & Technical Cooperation Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. The construction contract for the project was signed on December 5, 2012, and a groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 17, 2012. However, the project was later suspended due to violence and political instability in CAR. Then, on June 19, 2015, China’s Ambassador to CAR announced the resumption of project implementation.
staff_comments: The French project title is la construction du Centre de démonstration agricole de Mpoko. The Chinese project title is 援中非农业示范中心项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center Construction Project

# Description
On February 16, 2012, Chinese ambassador Sun Haichao and Central African Republic (CAR) Minister of International Cooperation Doroday Amy Marazapa signed a cooperation agreement to build a Agricultural Technology Demonstration Center in the prefecture of Ombella-M'Poko. The agreement stipulated that the Chinese Government would build the demonstration center free of charge. Shanxi International Economic & Technical Cooperation Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. The construction contract for the project was signed on December 5, 2012, and a groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 17, 2012. However, the project was later suspended due to violence and political instability in CAR. Then, on June 19, 2015, China’s Ambassador to CAR announced the resumption of project implementation.
justification: Agricultural technology demonstration center focused on social development and capacity building
evidence: Agricultural technology transfer, capacity building focus, no direct energy or environmental impacts mentioned

title: China donates anti-malaria drugs and medical equipment to Central African Republic's Ministry of Public Health
description: On November 9, 2012, the Chinese embassy donated anti-malaria drugs and medical equipment to the Central African Republic's Ministry of Public Health. The value of the donation is unknown. The extent of the donation is also unknown.  It is unclear if this donation is connected to other donations of anti-malaria supplies.

title: China donates 3000 tons of rice to Chad
description: On August 13, 2012, the handover ceremony for China's donation of 3,000 tons of rice was held in N’Djamena. Ambassador to Chad, Yang Guangyu, and the Minister of Agriculture and Irrigation, Jim Adumu, attended and signed the ceremony and agreement.  The value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China donates 3000 tons of rice to Chad

# Description
On August 13, 2012, the handover ceremony for China's donation of 3,000 tons of rice was held in N’Djamena. Ambassador to Chad, Yang Guangyu, and the Minister of Agriculture and Irrigation, Jim Adumu, attended and signed the ceremony and agreement.  The value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Food aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of rice for food security assistance, no energy or infrastructure components

title: China donates anti-malaria drugs to Chad in 2012
description: On December 12, 2012, China donated anti-malaria drugs to Chad. The agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhiqiang and Chadian Minister of Public Health. Government Counselor Qian Jin and the president of China-Chacha Friendship Hospital attended the signing ceremony. The donation came about as part of results of the Fifth Conference of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, where it was announced that China-Africa medical cooperation would be developed. The value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates anti-malaria drugs to Chad in 2012

# Description
On December 12, 2012, China donated anti-malaria drugs to Chad. The agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhiqiang and Chadian Minister of Public Health. Government Counselor Qian Jin and the president of China-Chacha Friendship Hospital attended the signing ceremony. The donation came about as part of results of the Fifth Conference of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, where it was announced that China-Africa medical cooperation would be developed. The value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of anti-malaria drugs, healthcare focus, no energy-related components
